story:
Help Make Star Cat Books Happen.

Do you love books and reading? Do you want people to have access to fantastic books and art from all around the world? I do. My name is Nancy and I need your help to bring books and a sense of art and community to the town of Bradford, Vermont. My passion is great art, great literature, and being able to give everyone access to them. My dream is "Star Cat Books," an independent bookstore that will bring a fantastic selection of literature to the people of Vermont. But in order to open I need your help. Don't worry, I have some fantastic rewards for you. By helping this store open, you are giving the gift of art, literature, and community to an entire town. I intend to make Star Cat Books something very special. I want people to feel the magic I felt when I was younger and there were independent bookstores everywhere. Will you help me give the joy of reading back to a community that needs it?

How much do I need to raise?

  • $8,000 minimum in contributions.

    I have already provided over $7,000 of my own money towards the acquisition of the existing store's inventory and fixtures (the sales price is $15,000).
    But I will need a new inventory system, modernized point-of-sale system, barcode scanners, and of course new stock — which will include both gently used/rare and new books. Those don't come free, unfortunately! Then there's the money I need to set aside to pay authors to come for signings and events. We want to make this store a place that people come to not just for books, but because it's truly special.

    That means any monies received over the $8,000 are needed to actually get the store up and running. Please do keep that in mind when you're contributing.

And what do you get out of it?

Note: Our final logo is yet to be finished by our excellent illustrator/designer, Timothy Zach.

Instead, for just our Indiegogo campaign we have a lovely, Special Edition logo made by a member of Comicmix, which is sponsoring us here: Evelyn Kriete made this, and we couldn't be more pleased!

That means your gift will be UNIQUE and one-of-a-kind. Only available during our Indiegogo campaign.

  • Any level: a limited-edition bookmark in a clear plastic sleeve with our cat & star logo on it

  • $10: a limited edition print of our resident crazy cat, printed just for you on heavy paper


  • $25: a die-cast pin of our limited-edition cat & star logo

  • $50: a heavy cotton book bag, with small exterior pouch, with our limited-edition cat & star logo on it


  • $100: a 15 oz. shiny white bistro mug & book bag with our limited-edition logo on it

    • $500 a specially signed book by:

      NEIL GAIMAIN
      or
      JANE YOLEN

    • tucked into one of our book bags just for you.


    Support your friendly neighborhood bookstore.

    We all hear it nowadays: Live local. Buy local. Support local. But how many of us do? Where I now live, the Upper Valley of New Hampshire and Vermont, along the Connecticut River — just north of Dartmouth College — people live that creed every day.

    (existing site of bookstore — to be renamed and relaunched as Star Cat Books, LLC)


    My background is in books — 30+ years'-worth of it.

    I've worked in the publishing business for over 30 years now, both in the production end of matters for major publishers on both coasts of the US (I still keep my hand in, in fact), and as a bookseller. My bookselling days go back to managing stores for Lauriats in the Boston, MA, area in the mid-1980s, and later on the North Shore of Boston in the later '80s. I love selling books, love talking to customers, love "hand-selling."

    I studied Children's Literature at Simmons College as part of their Master's program after my BA in the mid-1980s, and my specialty while working as a copy editor, proofreader, and developmental editor for publishers has been science fiction and fantasy.

    Hence the specialty for Star Cat Books: gently used and new books, specializing in science fiction and children's books.

    Online Presence

    I have a background in creating websites & integrating POS systems into them via databases, so we can modernize the existing bookstore inventory, including our new acquisitions of course, to allow our customers to finally be able to buy directly from Star Cat Books on the web as well as through programs such as Abe/Amazon Books.

    Ebooks: Friend or Foe?

    I know from ebooks — I've had to as ebooks have evolved over the last decade — and was one of the earliest adopters (I freely admit my complete and utter geekdom in having a Newton Message Pad and using it to read books...). We plan to participate in the indie bookstore platform with Kodo to provide our customers with a viable way to acquire and purchase ebooks both through us and at home.

    While distribution systems for publishers have changed radically over the last few years, creating a "the sky is falling" attitude in the media, those of us in the business for this long know that smaller bookstores themselves are not all going the way of the dinosaur. Why? Because indies have known all along that one must change constantly, keep with the flow. And to keep it local.

    Supporting Locally

    In keeping with our promise to uphold our "stay local" creed, we will be supporting local authors (of which there are many! did you know that the award-winning author of 1940's "shocker" The Lost Weekend lived right in this valley?) We will be supporting and coordinating with local stores and merchants (I've already joined the Bradford Merchants' Association as of this morning — we even meet at the locally owned coffee house, The Local Buzz), and we will be commissioning in as many local artisans' crafts to support the bookstore as possible.

    Bradford, VT, supports a vibrant community of merchants, including an old-fashioned 5¢ & 10¢ store (Hills), one of the best local restaurants & its lounge which is open late (right across the street from what will be my bookstore's location), a coffee shop, pizza joint, general store and hangout, ice cream (did you know New England sells, per capita, more ice cream than any other US region? go figure!), and it even hosts the home of Copeland Furniture — which makes furniture (the factory and factory store is in town) for The Company Store, featuring designs such as Frank Lloyd Wright's chairs and tables.

    (the opposite side of the street from the bookstore's location, downtown Bradford, VT.)


    What Else Do We Have Planned?

    We are planning author signings, readings, and events. Writers' workshops. Stitch 'n b*tch evenings for our local knitters. Coordination with local shops to co-host events, such as talks about outdoors sports led by Farmway, supported by hiking books on the nearby Appalachian Trail on special that month. Books on landscaping and gardening would be supported by talks from our local fantastic nursery, JM Landscaping & Garden Center. Draw-your-own comic book Saturdays in the back room, hosted by a local artist. And much more. The world is our oyster — we have so much talent in the Upper Valley, it's almost embarrassing. And everyone loves to share it with the others.

    (Bradford, VT, approaching from the south, on VT Rt 5)



    Other Ways You Can Help

    Please get out the word:

    Blog it.

    Reddit it.

    Share it via the Indiegogo Share Tool.

    Facebook it.

    Tweet it.

    Write it on someone's forehead (backwards, of course, so they can see it in the mirror!)

    Sky-write it.

    Tell your friends, your mom, your dog, your hamster, your roommate. Any and all lifeforms (and even some non-lifeforms) are more than welcome to contribute to the party. But remember: SHARE THIS! The bigger, the better.


    Why we all wished you lived here:

    So we could give you a big hug to thank you for just reading this. But especially because we think you'd love to see the Upper Valley and Bradford, Vermont, in particular. And, of course, Star Cat Books when it moves into the bookstore space in downtown Bradford.

    Spring, summer, fall, winter — every season is lovely here. I'm not just making that up. I'll be posting updates here with photos of weird and wonderful things you can see if you do end up visiting this area (and fun to see and read about even if you do never make it here).

    (view from my front porch this fall — I kid you not, every sunset here is a study in Maxfield Parrish art...)

So we could give you a big hug to thank you for just reading this. But especially because we think you'd love to see the Upper Valley and Bradford, Vermont, in particular. And, of course, Star Cat Books when it moves into the bookstore space in downtown Bradford.
Spring, summer, fall, winter — every season is lovely here. I'm not just making that up. I'll be posting updates here with photos of weird and wonderful things you can see if you do end up visiting this area (and fun to see and read about even if you do never make it here).


(view from my front porch this fall — I kid you not, every sunset here is a study in Maxfield Parrish art...)

story:
Positive Change in Marysville

Marysville, Washington is a community that has struggled to find a clear identity. What started as a lumber and farming community 30 miles north of Seattle, Washington has since given way to loosely connected pockets of commercial and residential neighborhoods. The town is host to a handful of small arts groups, but these groups have lacked a sense of community between them, and lacked a home in Marysville.

The Red Curtain Foundation for the Arts is a (501 c3) non-profit organization founded in 2009. The organization’s focus is on arts education and production, and produces a monthly country concert, has presented twelve plays, and offers classes in the arts for all ages. In addition, we have created partnerships with Pacific West Performing Arts in Snohomish, Trinity Lutheran College in Everett, and the Marysville Arts Coalition, among other groups. Our mission is to bring arts and art-based educational opportunities to under-served communities, and to help invigorate tourism, creativity, and community pride.

Though founded in Marysville, RCF has operated primarily out of the Historic Everett Theatre, but the goal was always to find a location in the Marysville area. In the summer of 2013, we were shown the former Dunn Lumber property at 1410 Grove Street. The 8,000 sq ft building sits on 1.5 acres near the city’s downtown core, and is conveniently located near shopping, dining, and public transportation.


Concept art showing the front of our new building.

Nationwide studies have shown the effect that a vibrant art center can have on its community. Terms like “Creative Placemaking” and “Ripple Effect” attempt to describe how such a center can transform cities from places where people go to sleep to neighborhoods that are alive and dynamic; where people live and take pride in their hometown.


The Need For A Community Center

At this time, there are no halls, theaters or large meeting spaces in Marysville, other than those associated with schools and churches. City officials are unable to call town meetings, schools have no options in town to hold dances or graduations off-campus. Local dance schools have to rent expensive halls in neighboring cities for their recitals.

By transforming the former lumber yard into a community meeting place, residents of Marysville will finally have a place to go for civic events of all kinds. They can come see their kids dance and create, and people of all ages will get the chance to act, sing, play music, and express themselves with pride without leaving their neighborhood.


The interior of the building, showing a temporary stage.

The arts center can also act as a central hub for all arts-related activities in town, no matter where they happen, by promoting community and school events. The proposed box office can serve as a central ticketing location for all local events, providing ease of purchase and saving other groups the cost of staffing and maintaining their own ticketing systems.

The green spaces planned around the facility will act as pockets of relaxation for our neighbors. The pocket park will be an ideal location for small gatherings and weddings, and will increase the versatility of the building’s use. By adding commercial kitchen equipment to our concessions area, the building will be able to support catering needs on-site.


A model showing the planned interior of the theater.



Our Immediate Goal

The building was first built in 1967, and has had very few updates since then. As such, the facility does not meet current regulations for fire safety or ADA compliance. These upgrades must be made immediately in order for RCF to begin programming on a regular basis. In addition, we are in need of funds for the down payment on the property. We are currently operating under a lease agreement with Dunn Lumber, and cannot make many of the necessary upgrades to the building to meet safety code until we have closed on the purchase.

Your contribution will help Red Curtain meets our immediate goals, make improvements on the building, and begin having a very real, positive effect on the residents and business owners in Marysville. Please consider donating today!

story:
Organization Background

We are The Imagine Foundation, and we were formed with one goal in mind... to end child slavery worldwide. 

We quickly realized that slavery isn't just an "over there" problem... it exists in our own back yard and affects our very own community. 

With this realization, we began our mission of education and activism…educating our own families, friends, schools, and neighbors about the realities of human trafficking and bringing those people together to build sustainable solutions that can be used in communities across the nation. 


The Need

When a human trafficking survivor is rescued, he or she may only have the clothes on their back. Our survivor bags are meant to give these survivors the supplies they need as they begin their fresh start and embark on their new lives.


Bag Contents

To support the survivor, they receive a bag that includes:

  • Gift cards for grocery stores & drug stores
  • Clothing 
  • Toiletries 
  • Food
  • Bus Passes

All items included in the survivor bags are manufactured without the use of child or forced labor and are not tested on animals. 


Goal

We will create ten bags, each bag valued at approximately $300 each. 

Once assembled, these bags will be distributed to local law enforcement officers in northeast Ohio who will pass them on to the trafficking survivors.

This is just the start. In the next year, we hope to create enough survivor bags to be distributed to any community or law enforcement officer who needs assistance in supporting a trafficking survivor (both state and nation wide!). 

NOTE: 

All donations go directly towards the first 10 bags, and any money left over will be put towards funding future survivor bags.


Awesome Stuff for You!

To show our appreciation, we have set up a few perks!

$10 - Virtual Shout-Out as an Honorary Freedom Fighter!

We will give you a virtual shout-out on our website! You will be officially named as a freedom fighter.

$25 - Bandana!

You will receive an awesome Imagine Foundation bandana! You (or your freedom fighting dog/cat) will be QUITE the talk of the town! Your walks in the park will never be the same again.

$50 - TShirt!

You will receive an amazing Imagine T-shirt! Literally everyone will want to know about your awesome freedom fighting superpowers! Can you handle it?!


Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't help out financially, you can always educate yourself!

There are numerous blog posts on our website to educate you about:

  • slavery
  • trafficking
  • what you can do

Don't underestimate the power of education, as well as what you personally can do. You can make a difference, and you will!

Thanks for stopping by!

story:
Friends,

I'm Tootie who many of you know by my food truck, Tooties' Mobile Kitchen and Catering.  I believe in giving back to the community and providing quality and professional service. I need your help! I'm opening a bar on our famous Rigsbee Street- the center of Durham's nightlife. 

    As a Durhamite, I remember spending an afternoon at the Regal Theatre and visiting local bars and grills with great food and drinks. Currently, Durham lacks places where you can get live bands and good entertainment.

    We're continuing Durham's legacy as the "Tastiest Town in the South" by serving quality comfort food and providing a friendly, relaxing bar. Our food will come hot and fresh off the food truck! Our venue will also serve as a meeting and special events facility.

    Your contribution will help us continue the legacy: Durham as the tastiest and friendliest town.


    What We Need & What You Get

    • We need to raise $25,000. Funds will go towards the following:
    • Indoor/Outdoor Carpet- $1000
    • Laminate Flooring- $200
    • Landscaping- $800
    • Vinyl Fencing-$2000
    • Patio Awning- $2000
    • Front Door- $400
    • Lightning and Electrical- $3000
    • Rear Glass Door-$400
    • Front Building Awning- $3000
    • Plumbing- $600
    • Interior Decorations- $6000
    • Exterior Decorations- $1600
    • Sunshades- $2000
    • Signs/Permits- $3000
    • Check out our unique and awesome perks. We've partnered with local food trucks, Funnel Bakes and Urban Entrees. 
    • I believe in our project and overall impact and I hope you do too!

    The Impact

    Our venue will serve the greater Triangle community and support local breweries, farmers, live bands, youth groups and most important families and friends like you. Your contributions will also helps us move one step further to provide a friendly space for our non profit, Build A Better Block with Tootie. We work with and support various community groups, local universities, City and County meetings and other projects such as:

    • Build A Better Block (https://www.facebook.com/BcubeD3?ref=bookmarks)
    • East Durham Children's Initiative
    • National Night Out
    • Longest Dinner Table in Durham (https://www.facebook.com/ThanksInSpring?ref=bookmarks)
    • Food Truck Rodeo
    • Teachers Appreciations
    • Walltown Children's Theatre
    • The Fare Project
    • Duke University Center for Documentary Studies (*check out our video filmed by students, http://vimeo.com/68908225)
    • GlaxoSmithKline Family Day
    We have a successful track record for providing quality fresh foods and great customer service to our customers through caterings and donations such as:
    • DPAC
    • Leadership Triangle (https://www.facebook.com/leadershiptri/photos/a.10151930307867654.1073741844.115837817653/10152061430192654/?type=3&theater)
    • Durham Parks/Rec
    • Family Reunions
    • Local Churches
    • Hayti Heritage Center
    *We hope that the community supports us as well as we have supported it!

      Other Ways You Can Help

      Please promote, support and share this fundraiser with your friends, family and coworkers! It only takes on click. Join our family today!

        We appreciate all that you do for this campaign.

story:
Where it gets better!

The Sacramento LGBT Community Center saved my life and continues to do so for countless people that walk through the doors. As a staff member at the Center I have found a purpose in my life and have been able to help many others. I am on a personal mission to raise funds for the Sacramento LGBT Community Center so it can continue to provide the life saving services that have impacted people for over 25 years. 

When I was 16 years old I was hospitalized for an attempt on my life. Coming out at a young age in small town in Northern California had left me feeling incredibly isolated. I didn't have many friends and didn't know any other gay people my age. When I was in the hospital one of my therapists told me about the Center, upon my release I sought it out. 

The Center youth group became my refuge 2 nights a week. On Wednesdays and Fridays I would drive 60 minutes round trip to the one place I could be myself. I made life long friends and met my first girlfriend. For the first time in my life I truly had a place where I belonged. 

10 years later I find myself working for the Center and helping kids and others the same way I was helped. I have seen the Center save countless people, now it's our turn to save the Center.

The Center needs help. Our budget is ridiculously low and because of it we only have an Executive Director and one (paid) staff member, two people can't do it all and volunteers can only commit so much. 

I don't want to see the place that helped me find community and hope close. There is no where else in Sacramento where I feel people can truly be themselves without fear of judgement of any kind. Don't let that disappear. 

What We Need & What You Get

  • I set a high goal on purpose-$100,000. This is only 2/3 of the annual operating budget. 
  • The Center needs staff! The demand for services has grown to point where more staff is needed to meet the ever expanding demands placed on staff and volunteers alike.
  • The Center also needs a different facility. Our current building is small and not 100% ADA accessible. To meet the growing need for services we need a larger facility that meets the diverse needs of the community center.
  • I am starting this on my own, so I won't have many perks to start, but if this campaign gets some steam I'm going to see what I can add. 

The Impact

What donating will do:

Improved staffing means better programming. Check out our website for what we currently offer and would love to improve on.

A new building means we will have a larger capacity for more programs.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate please spread the word, or check out saccenter.org.

If you are in the Sacramento area, or can volunteer remotely please fill out an application here.

story:
Lil Art Bodega's: 

Relax, Relate, Create Workshop Program

Lets keep it 100 as they say on the streets, i'm humble and speaks straight from the heart my name is Tanya Michelle i'm the owner and founder of the Lil Art Bodega. I've been running my business for 3 years out of Emergency Arts Building a community of collective spaces for creative businesses on Las Vegas Strip Downtown Fremont St. Now 3 years later my business is a growing art business. I'm been truly blessed surviving an aneurism on my brain, and now opening second L.A.B store. I'm happy to say i'm helping revitalize the downtown Fremont area by securing a store inside the new Container Park mall. The brainchild of Zappo CEO Tony Heish and his downtown project team. Now the community where the mall is located has a lot of talented artistic and creative underprivileged and disable youths which i have the pleasure giving back discounted art classes which some couldn't afford. So for the past year i've been working on a free art program that gives opportunity and support to our youths in the community. The program is complete with permits and legal mobo jumble i had to deal with.

Now i need help funding the rest of it. I will like to launch this free workshops program to underprivileged & disable youths in the Downtown Las Vegas community called “Relax Relate Create” in the fall of 2013 with the Grand Opening of the store. 

The work shop program consist of:

  • Art workshops: painting, graffiti, cartooning, drawing, graphics, mixed media
  • Having Fun & Enjoying what been created
  • Teach techniques from basic to advance skills
  • Special guest artists to teach
  • One on one structure teaching 
  • Teaching them how to sell market and distribute their art for a profit, 
  • Helping them to become business savvy in the art world. 
  • L.A.B will held exhibits of artwork and create a coffee table book, market and sale there artwork which will be a 80/20 split 80% to the youth and 20% to the program for expenses.  
  • The program comes with an Art Kit filled with the tools that best fits their art direction.
  • group art outings with there parents or care giver
  • Promote more family time because each student under the age of 17 years of age MUST have a parent,family member or caregiver over 18 years of age present at each class.

The youth today is smart from ages 7 to 17 this generation can become the next big thing in art. They just need guidance and structure and this is what RELAX RELATE CREATE is all about taking your time and teach, understanding them and feeding their creative minds.

Lil Art Bodega is a community mini mart for all things creative from Graphic services, Specialty Art Supplies, Local Fine art to Street art display, Pop up gallery for exclusive artists, Murals, illustrations, Mixed media, Exclusive prints, Vinyl toys, DIY items, Custom sneakers, T-shirts, Artists showcase, Relax Relate Create workshop program and more.

The L.A.B is surrounded a community of artists, musicians, fashion designer and tech guru’s folks who create stuff and Las Vegas Art District who needs a spot like ours on a daily bases. Our merchandise and service helps keep the door open with rent and operation cost. Any income that the Lil Art Bodega makes goes right back into the shop for costs, workshops and improvements. 

We are here to feed the creativity hunger in the community. We want to expand build and encourage our youth creative side and Lil Art Bodega is the place to get it done but we need your help!


What We Need & What You Get

Lil Art Bodega new store will have better amenities and space. We wanted the ability to function and service the community productively. The grand opening i will be announced in the fall of 2013. 

Since we are still under construction in the meantime we still need help. In order to run this workshop program effectively we need these items smart TV monitor, speakers,  Art station, Double sided easels & potable easels, Art kits & supplies, 27 MAC computer with CS5 or 6 illustrator and Photoshop, Printer copier scanner and a fax machine.

Here a detail breakdown on items we need:

  • $2,000 Signage promotional (banner, flyers, brochures, stickers, T-shirts etc.)
  • $1,500 smart TV monitor, mounting brackets 
  • $3,500 27' Mac computer and coverage
  • $1000 CS6 programs 
  • $1000  Speaker, headphones, stereo, USB(s), plugs, wiring 
  • $3,500 Art kits supplies paints oil acrylic brushes aprons etc., Art station, doubled sided easels, portable easels, backpacks, special needs easel (need to be built)
  • $1500 printer scanner copier inks, paper, fax
  • $1000 Build out, shelves, stools, fans, tables

Donations that come to us through Paypal actually transfer immediately. This allows us to actively work and progress as we are raising funds. Contributors will see the fruits of their generosity as we document our progress each step of the way on the lil art bodega's website

What You Get

Depending on which perk you pick you will receive from Lil Art Bodega: 

Artwork by Tanya Michelle

  • Buttons, stickers, postcards
  • Name or business logo listed on our website Thank You page 
  • Limited edition prints (exclusive for fund raiser)
  • 20x20 Hand Painted gallery canvas painting from the "Love Hard Love Always" series
  • 30x40 Hand Painted gallery canvas painting from the "Picasso Babe" series
  • Hand Painted LUV on Deck (skateboard) 
  • Commissioned gallery canvas Painting size is limited OR 3d Deck (skateboard)

The Impact From your donations, a community of young artists will thrive. Countless hours painting mix media illustration will be created, and many inspired young artists will be able to sale there art at the Lil art bodega online & in-store dedicated just for them and the sales will go to them. This will help encourage the community and spread art and beauty around our town and others places. If we make over our goal we will publish an EXCLUSIVE ART book of all the art work produced by the youth and program teachers and each person who donate $125 and more will received a book.

Other Ways You Can Help

Trust me we know times are hard that why we are asking for help and we know some people just can’t contribute money, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

  • Please get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • We are also open to other types of donations. If you or someone you know would be interested in donating any printing equipment, materials or art supplies, etc. or just funds without any perks we are humble and appreciate anything please send us an email at tanya@lilartbodega.com 
  • If you or a company would like to become a sponsor please email us for more info or check our website  www.lilartbodega.com

Be a part of our process join us! As Lil Art Bodega give back to underprivileged youth and help develop and grows, our entire community of youth one day at a time and other communities in the future!

Thanks for your support! Let feed that artistic hunger we can’t do it with you!

Relax, Relate, Create Workshop Program

Lets keep it 100 as they say on the streets, i'm humble and speaks straight from the heart my name is Tanya Michelle i'm the owner and founder of the Lil Art Bodega. I've been running my business for 3 years out of Emergency Arts Building a community of collective spaces for creative businesses on Las Vegas Strip Downtown Fremont St. Now 3 years later my business is a growing art business. I'm been truly blessed surviving an aneurism on my brain, and now opening second L.A.B store. I'm happy to say i'm helping revitalize the downtown Fremont area by securing a store inside the new Container Park mall. The brainchild of Zappo CEO Tony Heish and his downtown project team. Now the community where the mall is located has a lot of talented artistic and creative underprivileged and disable youths which i have the pleasure giving back discounted art classes which some couldn't afford. So for the past year i've been working on a free art program that gives opportunity and support to our youths in the community. The program is complete with permits and legal mobo jumble i had to deal with.
Now i need help funding the rest of it. I will like to launch this free workshops program to underprivileged & disable youths in the Downtown Las Vegas community called “Relax Relate Create” in the fall of 2013 with the Grand Opening of the store. 


The work shop program consist of:


Art workshops: painting, graffiti, cartooning, drawing, graphics, mixed media
Having Fun & Enjoying what been created
Teach techniques from basic to advance skills
Special guest artists to teach
One on one structure teaching 
Teaching them how to sell market and distribute their art for a profit, 
Helping them to become business savvy in the art world. 
L.A.B will held exhibits of artwork and create a coffee table book, market and sale there artwork which will be a 80/20 split 80% to the youth and 20% to the program for expenses.  
The program comes with an Art Kit filled with the tools that best fits their art direction.
group art outings with there parents or care giver
Promote more family time because each student under the age of 17 years of age MUST have a parent,family member or caregiver over 18 years of age present at each class.



The youth today is smart from ages 7 to 17 this generation can become the next big thing in art. They just need guidance and structure and this is what RELAX RELATE CREATE is all about taking your time and teach, understanding them and feeding their creative minds.

Lil Art Bodega is a community mini mart for all things creative from Graphic services, Specialty Art Supplies, Local Fine art to Street art display, Pop up gallery for exclusive artists, Murals, illustrations, Mixed media, Exclusive prints, Vinyl toys, DIY items, Custom sneakers, T-shirts, Artists showcase, Relax Relate Create workshop program and more.
The L.A.B is surrounded a community of artists, musicians, fashion designer and tech guru’s folks who create stuff and Las Vegas Art District who needs a spot like ours on a daily bases. Our merchandise and service helps keep the door open with rent and operation cost. Any income that the Lil Art Bodega makes goes right back into the shop for costs, workshops and improvements. 
We are here to feed the creativity hunger in the community. We want to expand build and encourage our youth creative side and Lil Art Bodega is the place to get it done but we need your help!

What We Need & What You Get
Lil Art Bodega new store will have better amenities and space. We wanted the ability to function and service the community productively. The grand opening i will be announced in the fall of 2013. 
Since we are still under construction in the meantime we still need help. In order to run this workshop program effectively we need these items smart TV monitor, speakers,  Art station, Double sided easels & potable easels, Art kits & supplies, 27 MAC computer with CS5 or 6 illustrator and Photoshop, Printer copier scanner and a fax machine.
Here a detail breakdown on items we need:

$2,000 Signage promotional (banner, flyers, brochures, stickers, T-shirts etc.)
$1,500 smart TV monitor, mounting brackets 
$3,500 27' Mac computer and coverage
$1000 CS6 programs 
$1000  Speaker, headphones, stereo, USB(s), plugs, wiring 
$3,500 Art kits supplies paints oil acrylic brushes aprons etc., Art station, doubled sided easels, portable easels, backpacks, special needs easel (need to be built)
$1500 printer scanner copier inks, paper, fax
$1000 Build out, shelves, stools, fans, tables

Donations that come to us through Paypal actually transfer immediately. This allows us to actively work and progress as we are raising funds. Contributors will see the fruits of their generosity as we document our progress each step of the way on the lil art bodega's website

What You Get
Depending on which perk you pick you will receive from Lil Art Bodega: 
Artwork by Tanya Michelle


Buttons, stickers, postcards
Name or business logo listed on our website Thank You page 
Limited edition prints (exclusive for fund raiser)
20x20 Hand Painted gallery canvas painting from the "Love Hard Love Always" series
30x40 Hand Painted gallery canvas painting from the "Picasso Babe" series
Hand Painted LUV on Deck (skateboard) 
Commissioned gallery canvas Painting size is limited OR 3d Deck (skateboard)


The Impact From your donations, a community of young artists will thrive. Countless hours painting mix media illustration will be created, and many inspired young artists will be able to sale there art at the Lil art bodega online & in-store dedicated just for them and the sales will go to them. This will help encourage the community and spread art and beauty around our town and others places. If we make over our goal we will publish an EXCLUSIVE ART book of all the art work produced by the youth and program teachers and each person who donate $125 and more will received a book.


Other Ways You Can Help
Trust me we know times are hard that why we are asking for help and we know some people just can’t contribute money, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

Please get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
We are also open to other types of donations. If you or someone you know would be interested in donating any printing equipment, materials or art supplies, etc. or just funds without any perks we are humble and appreciate anything please send us an email at tanya@lilartbodega.com 
If you or a company would like to become a sponsor please email us for more info or check our website  www.lilartbodega.com


Be a part of our process join us! As Lil Art Bodega give back to underprivileged youth and help develop and grows, our entire community of youth one day at a time and other communities in the future!
Thanks for your support! Let feed that artistic hunger we can’t do it with you!

story:
(english summary below)

Unsere Vision: 

Wir möchten ein veganes Café in Duisburg eröffnen, indem sich viele unserer eigenen Wünsche und Vorstellungen von einem Café widerspiegeln. Das bedeutet, dass wir vollkommen vegane, biologische und ökologische Angebote haben, bei denen der Genuss im Vordergrund steht. Fair trade, regional und saisonal. Ein kleines Sortiment an veganen Lebensmitteln sollt ihr genauso bei uns erstehen können, wie individuelle Einzelstücke von Künstler*Innen und Bastler*Innen, die bei uns ihre Sachen ausstellen und verkaufen.

Und weil gutes Essen noch mehr Spaß macht, wenn man zusätzlich noch etwas erleben kann, planen wir in unserem Café verschiedenste Veranstaltungen: Konzerte, Lesungen, Spieleabende, Ausstellungen und weitere kulturelle Events sollen die Krümelküchenfreunde glücklich machen.

Ein bisschen was zu uns: 

Dennis: Dennis ist gebürtiger Duisburger, Germanist, Anglist, Musiker, Game Designer und Autor. Als Schlagzeuger hat er jahrelange Erfahrungen auf und hinter der Bühne sammeln können. Dennis' Aufgabe in der Krümelküche ist der Service und der Veranstaltungsbereich. 

Sarah: Sarah ist gelernte Kommunikationswirtin, ihr Herz schlägt aber vor allem für Ihre Kuchen, Torten, Eintöpfe, Aufläufe und alles was sonst noch schmeckt. Sarah wird in der Krümelküche die Küchenchefin sein und darf dann endlich mit vollem Eifer ihre Liebe zum Kochen und Backen ausleben.

Einige von Euch haben sicherlich schon die ein oder andere leckere Kostprobe von Sarah in unserem Guerilla-Café probieren dürfen. Damit haben wir seit anderthalb Jahren Erfahrungen sammeln können: https://www.facebook.com/cafemousebear


Was wir schon haben: 

Wir haben ein sehr gut ausgearbeitetes Konzept in Form von einem Businessplan und ein wunderschönes Ladenlokal. Dieses wird momentan komplett umgebaut und soweit fertiggestellt, dass wir uns nur noch um die Wandgestaltung, den Fußboden und natürlich die Einrichtung kümmern müssen. 

Für das Interieur haben wir im Laufe der Zeit bereits einige Möbel angesammelt, die alle einen schönen Platz im Café bekommen sollen. Außerdem lassen wir ein paar lokale Künstler und Designer auf unsere Wände los, um sie individuell und geschmackvoll zu gestalten. 


Was wir noch brauchen: 

Für die Austattung und die Renovierungsarbeiten im Café benötigen wir eine Summe von 20.000€. 

Diese Summe benötigen wir für die Renovierung und die gesamte Aussttattung der Küche. Das beinhaltet sowohl die technischen Geräte als auch die Küche selber. Neben einem Kühlschrank, einem Ofen bzw. Herd und einer Gastronomiespülmaschine benötigen wir außerdem diverse Küchenmöbel. Hinzu kommen die Kleingeräte und Arbeitsmaterialien wie Töpfe, Pfannen und Werkzeuge. 

Für den Gästebereich benötigen wir eine Kuchentheke, einen Getränkekühlschrank und das Herzstück eines jeden Cafés: Die Kaffee- und Espressomaschine sowie die dazugehörigen Kaffeemühlen. 


Was IHR davon habt: 

BAM! Ihr bekommt also ein neues veganes Lieblingscafé, in dem ganz viel Herzblut steckt und wo Ihr Bücher lesend oder Spiele spielend schlemmen und entspannen könnt. Außerdem stehen Euch einige tolle Perks als Belohnung für Eure Spende zur Verfügung. Awesome!

Neben leckeren Cupcakes und Torten könnt ihr auch Jutebeutel oder T-Shirts bekommen. Yippee-Ki-Yay! Zudem gibt es Backkurse bei Sarah oder gar die Benennung eines Sandwiches oder Mittagsgerichts nach Euch. Legendary! Und das sind nur einige der Perks, die zur Verfügung stehen. Schaut Euch um. Es ist sicherlich für jeden etwas dabei.
Spenden könnt ihr für die Perks mit Kreditkarte oder bequem per PayPal.

Außerdem werden wir in unserem Ladenlokal eine Dankestafel aufhängen, auf der wir unsere Unterstützer und Helfer namentlich nennen, sodass wir und andere jeden Tag sehen können, wer uns geholfen hat, unseren Traum zu erfüllen.


Was ihr sonst tun könnt: 

Wir sind für jeden Betrag, den Ihr spenden könnt dankbar. So kommen wir unserem Ziel immer näher.
Und auch wenn Ihr nicht spenden könnt: wenn Ihr allen von der Kampagne erzählt, erreichen wir bestimmt genug Leute, die etwas spenden möchten. Also freuen wir uns auch, wenn Ihr die Kampagne fleißig in allen sozialen Netzen teilt und Euren Freunden und Familien davon erzählt.

So oder so danken wir Euch 1000fach für Eure Hilfe und Unterstützung!



_________________________________________________________________


ENGLISH SUMMARY

The initial idea:

Since August 2012 Sarah and Dennis organize vegan events at their home once a month where friends can come over to eat Sarah's selfmade vegan cakes, cookies, cupcakes, muffins, coffee and so forth. The experience they gathered from that made them want to open a real coffee house even more.

But it should not stay a simple place to eat and drink coffee. Sarah and Dennis’ vision is to organize small concerts, readings, art exhibitions, maybe some stand up comedy, board game evenings and other cultural events.

About Sarah and Dennis:
Sarah and Dennis are a vegan couple from Duisburg, Germany. Dennis is a drummer, author and game designer, Sarah is a freelance baker. Together they have the vision of opening a vegan coffee house in their hometown Duisburg.

What they need from you:
They already found a place which is being refurbished right now. After that they need to decorate the guest area, set up the kitchen with professional kitchen tools and buy a really good but expensive coffee machine.

For that they need the help from as many people as possible.


What YOU get from that:
 The perks that come with supporting this campaign are really something. From discount on all products over a free cake, a limited supporter t-shirt up to a baking session with head chef Sarah or even a complete and private dinner for four people with live music and you name it. There’s something for everybody. And every buck counts. Even if you’re from a different country you can help this couple make their dream come true and to make their city a little bit more vegan.

story:
Most importantly, I want to make it clear that this is not a "charitable donation" but more of a "party fund".

If you're interested in donating money to the Community itself (and goodness knows we would be greatful!) then please email us seperately at communityholytrinity@gmail.com. Another great cause that you could send money to is The Crabgrass Christian Initiave: http://goo.gl/tbNpO

I also encourage you to send me money here so that we can have a great party!

What is Twelfth Night?

Twelfth Night is the last night of Christmas (you know, when your true love gave you those drummers drumming) and is traditionally a time of misrule, reversal, and screw-this-middle-of-the-winter-crap excess. Men dress like women and vice-versa (whatever that means, in this group) and everyone eats spicy foods like pepper and ginger. There is often a bit of drinking, as well...

The Community of the Holy Trinity has been having an annual Twelfth Night party since 2005, with live music, carols, poetry readings, and general madness. 

What do we need money for?

The party in 2013 will be just as fantastic even if no one contributes a dime here, and to tell the truth, $500 was the minimum ammount that we could ask for via IndieGoGo, and we'll do fine on a lot less (we can keep the money, even if we don't make the full goal here).

One thing we traditionally pass the hat for is to pay for child care for this party--it's not child friendly, but we have a number of friends that wouldn't be able to come unless they hire a baby sitter.

Regardless of how much y'all kick in, me and the rest of the Community will certainly have a bunch of liquor, some decent wine, a big pot of wassail and some tasty food. But of course if had $500 to spend we could really have some nice things! Maybe a gigantic King Cake this year?

What if I can't contribute money?

Well, I hope it's clear that this is just a sidenote, really. Please join us, and bringing a bottle of wine or a plate of cookies is totally fine. In fact, it's always been very important to us that everyone be welcome at 12th Night--there's absolutely no need to bring anything at all. Just show up and celebrate the new year with us!

story:
Short Summary

Preservation Kentucky is working with Bethlehem High School (BHS), an independent Catholic school, in Bardstown to save the endangered Anatok house from demolition.  Anatok is an antebellum mansion, built by Catholic merchant Charles Hayden in 1847, known for its most famous resident—Black Catholic activist Daniel Rudd.  Born into slavery on this site in 1854, Daniel Rudd went on to found the National Black Catholic Congress and established the American Catholic Tribune—“the only Catholic Journal owned and published by colored men.” Rudd is the subject of a new book on his life by Professor Gary Agee titled, “A Cry for Justice: Daniel Rudd and His Life in Black Catholicism, Journalism, and Activism, 1854-1933.”   If preserved, this historic site would be the only site directly associated with the rise of Black Catholicism in Bardstown—known as the cradle of Catholicism on the Western Frontier in the early 19th century.

Preservation Kentucky (PK) has teamed up with the Kentucky Trust for Historic Preservation and local groups to help BHS save Anatok and incorporate it into their campus as a center for fine arts.  This partnership has resulted in a plan with BHS to use the house as classrooms for their flourishing visual arts program and an enhanced choral program. For more information on Bethlehem High School please visit: http://www.bethlehemhigh.org/

However, BHS cannot afford to preserve Anatok from their general revenues.  So, PK has offered to help them plan and fundraise to convert Anatok into fine arts classroom space, while preserving its historic character.  PK has consulted with architects, contractors, and roofers and developed an initial renovation cost of $500,000.  If we cannot meet this goal by April 30, Anatok—an important piece of Black Catholic history—will be demolished.

Why is this important?  Anatok house is the only remaining site in Kentucky, directly associated with Daniel Rudd and Black Catholicism-except for his resting place in the St Joseph Cemetery in Bardstown.  BHS has great plans to rehab and use this important historic site—

Can you help us meet our goal? 

What We Need & What You Get

Preservation Kentucky needs to raise at least 500,000, of which we expect $100,000 from Indiegogo.  The remainder of the funds will be raised privately through traditional methods.

Any funds we raise—on this website—or through traditional methods will go directly to Bethlehem High School (BHS) from Preservation Kentucky to rehabilitate Anatok.  These funds will be restricted and spent only to rehab the building into classroom space. 

If we cannot raise at least $500,000 before our deadline of April 30, 2013, we will refund the money given to us, unless you expressly request that we use it for other preservation efforts.  All donations to Preservation Kentucky are tax-deductible. PK is a 501(c)3 non-profit organization and your gift is therefore tax- deductible to the fullest extent allowable under the law. 

*Please be aware that donations via this website, rather than through pledges or checks, cannot be refunded in full, due to the 6% processing fee charged by Indiegogo for use of their platform.  If necessary (which we hope it won't be), we will refund the amount minus the Indiegogo charge directly to you.

This is a special project fund.  Regular donors to Bethlehem High School or Preservation Kentucky are urged to continue their generous support to these groups and consider any donation to Anatok as above and beyond what they would normally give. 

We offer a few unique perks that we hope you will enjoy. 

-A Drawing or Historic Photo of the house will be sent to the first 100 people who pledge $25 or more.  This will be available in June 2013

-Donors who give more than $100 are eligible for a Hard-Hat Construction tour of Anatok during the rehab process this summer. More details will be forwarded as the funds are raised.

-For a $1,000 donation, we will memorialize your contribution in a creative way at the site.  At the project’s initiation, we will work with the architect to develop an interesting, non-traditional way to thank you for your generous gift.  This will be communicated to you as we get the details.

-For a $5,000 donation, our local group will sponsor a Dinner at historic Wickland in Bardstown, with special guest speaker Dr Gary Agee, author of the seminal work on Daniel Rudd. http://visitbardstown.com/wickland/

The Impact

The impact of your donation is simple: your generosity will mean that this important house will remain standing and in service of the community of Bardstown.

It will mean that high school students at Bethlehem High School will have a beautiful historic building in which they can learn and flourish.

It will mean respect for the legacy of Daniel Rudd, a man who was able to rise from the chains of slavery to become one of the most important Black Catholic thinkers in the United States.

It will mean that one less important historic building will rest in our landfills.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot contribute to this campaign but feel it is important—please share with your family and friends and help us preserve this important historic building.  Share this on your Facebook page, on twitter, through email, and any other way possible to get more folks engaged.  It takes all of us to make a difference!

Preservation Kentucky (PK) has teamed up with the Kentucky Trust for Historic Preservation and local groups to help BHS save Anatok and incorporate it into their campus as a center for fine arts.  This partnership has resulted in a plan with BHS to use the house as classrooms for their flourishing visual arts program and an enhanced choral program. For more information on Bethlehem High School please visit: http://www.bethlehemhigh.org/
However, BHS cannot afford to preserve Anatok from their general revenues.  So, PK has offered to help them plan and fundraise to convert Anatok into fine arts classroom space, while preserving its historic character.  PK has consulted with architects, contractors, and roofers and developed an initial renovation cost of $500,000.  If we cannot meet this goal by April 30, Anatok—an important piece of Black Catholic history—will be demolished.
Why is this important?  Anatok house is the only remaining site in Kentucky, directly associated with Daniel Rudd and Black Catholicism-except for his resting place in the St Joseph Cemetery in Bardstown.  BHS has great plans to rehab and use this important historic site—
Can you help us meet our goal? 
What We Need & What You Get
Preservation Kentucky needs to raise at least 500,000, of which we expect $100,000 from Indiegogo.  The remainder of the funds will be raised privately through traditional methods.
Any funds we raise—on this website—or through traditional methods will go directly to Bethlehem High School (BHS) from Preservation Kentucky to rehabilitate Anatok.  These funds will be restricted and spent only to rehab the building into classroom space. 
If we cannot raise at least $500,000 before our deadline of April 30, 2013, we will refund the money given to us, unless you expressly request that we use it for other preservation efforts.  All donations to Preservation Kentucky are tax-deductible. PK is a 501(c)3 non-profit organization and your gift is therefore tax- deductible to the fullest extent allowable under the law. 
*Please be aware that donations via this website, rather than through pledges or checks, cannot be refunded in full, due to the 6% processing fee charged by Indiegogo for use of their platform.  If necessary (which we hope it won't be), we will refund the amount minus the Indiegogo charge directly to you.
This is a special project fund.  Regular donors to Bethlehem High School or Preservation Kentucky are urged to continue their generous support to these groups and consider any donation to Anatok as above and beyond what they would normally give. 
We offer a few unique perks that we hope you will enjoy. 
-A Drawing or Historic Photo of the house will be sent to the first 100 people who pledge $25 or more.  This will be available in June 2013
-Donors who give more than $100 are eligible for a Hard-Hat Construction tour of Anatok during the rehab process this summer. More details will be forwarded as the funds are raised.
-For a $1,000 donation, we will memorialize your contribution in a creative way at the site.  At the project’s initiation, we will work with the architect to develop an interesting, non-traditional way to thank you for your generous gift.  This will be communicated to you as we get the details.
-For a $5,000 donation, our local group will sponsor a Dinner at historic Wickland in Bardstown, with special guest speaker Dr Gary Agee, author of the seminal work on Daniel Rudd. http://visitbardstown.com/wickland/
The Impact
The impact of your donation is simple: your generosity will mean that this important house will remain standing and in service of the community of Bardstown.
It will mean that high school students at Bethlehem High School will have a beautiful historic building in which they can learn and flourish.
It will mean respect for the legacy of Daniel Rudd, a man who was able to rise from the chains of slavery to become one of the most important Black Catholic thinkers in the United States.
It will mean that one less important historic building will rest in our landfills.
Other Ways You Can Help
If you cannot contribute to this campaign but feel it is important—please share with your family and friends and help us preserve this important historic building.  Share this on your Facebook page, on twitter, through email, and any other way possible to get more folks engaged.  It takes all of us to make a difference!

story:
ComMuNIty cONnecTIOn

Bringing Family and Friends Together While Having Fun

On Friday nights at The Hang Out, we pull together families and friends to have fun with each other. Every home is different and because of the daily struggles of life, FUN can sometimes be pushed to the back burner. For single parents, long hours at work to make ends meet, helping with homework, and a  lack of positive friendships for their child are also very challenging. The list goes on and on. We at “The Hang Out” do our best to share the love of God in words, actions, and attitude while building a genuine community in the neighborhood where we live. And it works! Not only is it fun for the kids, we also find ourselves providing solutions for some of the parent’s problems. Everyone leaves with a smile!

A Parent's Testimony

http://vimeo.com/65948400

KidS cONnecTIOn

Where Kids Can Be Kids ( even if they are 40 yrs old :-) )

You’ve heard that everything is BIG in Texas and LOVE is no exception. It started off slow but eventually neighbors and some parents chipped in with food. We as a community watch out for our neighbor’s kids.  We are in need of a commercial building for more space; however, we do not want the children to lose the warm feeling of being loved. It is important to “The Hang Out” that we provide a safe, supportive environment.

rESouRcE cONnecTIOn

Help Students Achieve Academically 

While Sharing The Love Of God

Once “The Hang Out” is in a larger place we can call HOME, we will provide even more programs and activities for our youth. “The Hang Out’s” plan is to build a foundation for students to actively discover self-awareness through:

* Parent Support and Counseling

* Goal Setting and Character Development

* After School Tutoring

* School Supply and Uniform Giveaway

* Youth Outdoor Activities

* Fishing Trips

* Game Nights

* Movie Nights

* Father and Daughter Dinner Nights

* Mother and Son Dinner Nights  

* Parenting and Counselling

* Bible Studies

Bringing Unity In A Community

A Strong, Safe, Supportive Environment For Our Kids Future

With donations and partnerships we can provide opportunities for our neighbors to take proactive steps toward a hope-filled, positive lifestyle and environment. At “The Hang Out” we can create a place for our Kids to be Kids!  

How did tHe HanG OuT get started?

The Hang Out started a couple of years ago as a family night at the Richardson’s home. Family, friends, and neighborhood kids would participate in playing video games. It began with Wii Sports then moved over to the Xbox 360 Kinect. After talking to parents in the neighborhood and through word of mouth, “The Hangout” rapidly grew. We now have as many as twenty-five kids along with parents participating and the numbers keeps growing! As the numbers increase we realized the demand for snacks was great so we began buying snacks such as cookies, popcorn, and hot dogs, just to name a few. We couldn’t keep enough water in the refrigerator for all the thirsty kids so we invested in a water cooler. Even though all of snacks and everything were out of our own pockets, we loved doing it! Some of the children wanted to watch movies on Friday nights as well, which is also a Richardson tradition. Now our Friday nights alternate between games and movies. The Hang Out is a place where kids can be kids while having fun and spending time with their family and friends. We are in need of donations and a larger place on the Southwest side of Houston, Texas. Once in our new place we will also start our after school programs as well as our kids TV show where the kids run the show!

wHAt wE nEEd at The hAnG oUT

We are in need of a commercial building in the Southwest Houston area. Our home has become overwhelmed with kids and parents and we cannot accommodate everyone at the same time. We also need a van for picking up and taking home kids that want to come. Some live as far as 40+ miles away.  In the building we will need a Big Screen TV, Xbox 360 Kinect, and a Blue ray Player with a Sound system for our  Game and Movie nights. We Need Computers for the after school programs. Food and snack donations must be sealed and store bought for the safety of the kids. Last but not least, cash donations are always welcome to help cut cost.

 WE NEED YOUR HELP.....FUND tHe HaNgOuT

Last but not least, cash donations are always welcome to help cut cost.

story:
This year Foundation Beyond Belief (FBB) is sponsoring the Pathfinders Project, a year-long volunteer journey, taking four humanist volunteers across the world to work in education, clean water, human rights and construction projects, and to evaluate programs for inclusion in a future Humanist Service Corps (HSC). The HSC will be a proud moment for all nonbelievers. Like the Peace Corps, the HSC will serve their fellowman in the cause of peace by living and working in developing countries, but with more focus on encouraging and demonstrating the generosity and compassion of secular humanists.

Since FBB's launched in 2010, we have raised over $400,000 to fight blood cancers through the Leukemia & Lymphoma Society. We have raised close to a million in just three years to help other charities in the name of humanism.

What We Need & What You Get

Here's where you come in. A large portion of the expenses for this project will be funded through drives by the four individual Pathfinders and grants from major donors. For the remaining portion -- just over $16,000 -- we turn to the generous humanist community (these figures are variable): 

Travel: $4,000
Insurance: $1,000
Housing: $2,500
Food: $1,000
Project Donations (for construction materials, etc.): $6,250
Pathfinder Stipends: $400
Contingency & Misc $1,000

In exchange for your generous donation, you will not only know that you are helping individuals in developing countries as well as our gratitude, you will also receive a little something depending on the amount you contribute. Check out the "perks" to the right.

The Impact

The four Pathfinders will have a big impact on the areas that they are working in. Also, they are the pilot program for the Humanist Services Corps which will  eventually become the largest volunteer services organization for secular humanists. The initial project has three primary goals: 

1) complete clean water, education, and sustainability projects in Asia, Africa, and Latin America. 

2) engage in dialogue across religious, cultural, and ethnic boundaries.

3) assess countries and partner organizations with the ultimate goal of selecting one site for launching the Humanist Service Corps.

Locales

TASK Trenton Area Soup Kitchen

Bridge of Life School (Cambodia)

Kasese Humanist Primary School (Uganda)

Uganda Humanist Schools Trust (Uganda)

Leo Igwe Research Project (Northern Ghana)

Children of the Border (Domican Republic)

Water Equador (Ecuador)

Aquayuda (Colombia)

Safe Passage (Guatemala)

Avivara (Guatemala)

Pathfinders Project and the Humanist Service Corps will enable humanists to put their values into action, thereby demonstrating those values to the world. Pathfinders Project has been described by Hemant Mehta as "the ultimate service project for Humanists" and by James Croft as "a life-changing opportunity." Certainly, Pathfinders Project will have a meaningful impact on each of the communities visited and a profound effect on each of the Pathfinders. Furthermore, Pathfinders Project will shape the humanist movement for years to come. In taking the first step toward launching the Humanist Service Corps, the Pathfinders are building the structure of a flagship program not just for Foundation Beyond Belief, but for the entire humanist movement.

So far, FBB has been successful in its previous endeavors. We have raised tens of thousands of dollars for disaster relief efforts here and abroad. We have a continuously growing group of volunteers beyond belief and we are one of the LLS' biggest contributors. All of this is done in the name of compassionate humanism. 

Other Ways You Can Help

You might not have the money to contribute at this time but we still need your help! Please let others know about this great project and share the link to this page.
 

FAQ

1. Q - Why should someone join the Humanist Service Corps instead of the Peace Corps?
 
A - The Humanist Service Corps and the Peace Corps have similar service aims, but function for different communities.  
 
The stated aims of the Peace Corps are to (1) provide technical assistance, (2) expose people outside the U.S. to U.S. citizens, and (3) expose U.S. citizens to people outside the U.S.
 
The Humanist Service Corps will (1) engage Humanists from around the globe in service, (2) provide technical assistance, (3) expose people unfamiliar with Humanism to Humanists, and (3) expose Humanists to people from other cultures around the world.  

2. Q - Will the volunteers be safe?
 
A - The embassies have been contacted and are aware of the duration of their stay and the nature of the work. In addition safety and preparatory measures have been well research and was done so prior to writing up the Pathfinders Project application documents. Insurance is also being provided.

story:
Hello body art fans!

We are looking to have the sign installed for Planet X Tattoo & Supply in Aurora, Colorado. This will help us to let everyone in the neighborhood know about our great new shop.

We are offering excellent tattoo work, body piercing, and original music by my theatre group, Planet X Productions, for folks too far out of town to come get a tattoo. Come get some work, or give one as a gift. Just in time for the holidays!

Thank you in advance for considering supporting this project. Our little community of body artists are forever grateful!

-Seth Iniguez Bertoni

Robot the Rock Opera Original Cast Recording

As a thank you at the $15 supporter level, receive a double CD set of Robot the Rock Opera, by Seth Iniguez Bertoni and Fredd Bowers of The Next Pony. Check out promotional videos No Human Rights and Down in the Works.

Body Piercing Certificate

At the $15 level, receive one certificate for a body piercing. Jewelry included!

One Hour Tattoo

At the $50 supporter level, receive a certificate for one hour of tattoo work. A great value and opportunity for a holiday gift!

Two Hour Tattoo

At the $100 supporter level, receive a certificate for two hours of tattoo work.

All rewards can be mailed out within 48 hours of contribution to a US address of your choice. Alternately, certificates can be picked up in person, or received by email for speed of availability. Please send preferred delivery method when you support.

Any questions, feel free to contact me at sethi23@yahoo.com, or 303-745-0959

Thanks for your time and support!

-Seth

story:
What the heck is Area 15?

Area 15 is a small business incubator located in Charlotte NC at the intersection of North Davidson and 15th Street in the NoDa arts district. This 23,000 sq. foot building is itself an evolving piece of art with a community heart, and includes studio spaces for artists, non-profits and businesses alike. Currently hosting creatives of all shapes and sizes, cutting-edge media personnel, a 24/7 prayer room, a “Freestore”, all kinds of craftsmen, builders, designers and more, Area 15 is re-defining what it means to do business. 

What's this fundraiser for?

Friends of Area 15 are teaming together to raise $35,000 to finish building the courtyard which includes completing the back stage, adding two more bathrooms to the building and renovating the back patio for visitors, concerts and events. We'd also like to fix up the parking lot and make both cosmetic and functional changes to the building.

The Impact

Our vision is to empower the community of Area 15 by increasing the accessibility and functionality of the facilities, as well as to drive more traffic to the Area 15 businesses by creating a meeting place for locals to enjoy. Picture this: neighborhood movie nights in the courtyard, summer evening acoustic shows, local artist "gallery crawls", fashion shows, community cook-outs... all right here in your backyard! 

Other Ways You Can Help

Share, share, share! Post on Facebook and Twitter, write about us on your blog, email your mom about this fundraiser... every little bit helps!

www.facebook.com/Area15CLT

www.areafifteen.com

story:
Wyatt Update #4 – October 27

Wyatt’s family had a great birthday party on October 27 to celebrate him
turning 4 years old on October 29! There were lots of family and friends
there, great food and cake (thanks to everyone for their help!) and some
awesome birthday gifts for Wyatt (as well as some great little-brother gifts
for Ryder!).

Wyatt had spent most of the week leading up to his party in the hospital
again. He developed another bladder infection, and had some problems
with his chemo port site. So they cultured his urine, which took a few days
to grow out, and had to sedate him in order to insert a new line for delivery
of his morphine and the new antibiotics for infection. He also received
another chemo treatment. Luckily, they were able to discharge him on
Friday, and we were all very happy that he felt up to attending his birthday
party on Saturday. He seemed to enjoy it quite a bit, though you could tell
he certainly wasn’t feeling like his old self. He had to wear a mask during
the entire event to protect him from germs, since his immune system is so
compromised. But boy, what a trooper he is - he never complained about
that once!

Wyatt is scheduled to have an MRI on Monday, October 29 (his actual
birthday), to assess his current condition in regards to spread of the
disease. We are all hoping for good news! Then, he is scheduled to have
surgery on Friday, Nov. 2 to have his bladder and prostate removed. It will
be a lengthy surgery, estimated by his urologist to last appx. 8 hours.

Let's keep positive thoughts flowing Wyatt's way - we will post updates as
we get them!

Wyatt's family thanks everyone for all of the support!

 

Update #3 - Wyatt Update - 10/12/12

Wyatt has been admitted to Detroit Children’s Hospital for his next round of
chemotherapy treatment. He will receive chemotherapy everyday for 5 days, go home for 2 days, and then be re-admitted for another round of 5 day treatment. The plan right now is that he’ll then have an MRI to see if any tumor shrinkage has occurred, and to access whether there has been any spread of the tumor through the bladder wall, sphincter muscle or any other organs. He is scheduled for surgery to remove the bladder and prostate (and possibly the sphincter muscle) on November 2. Amount of spread of the disease will determine whether the doctors will plan on using radiation as part of his treatment. That will consist of either traditional radiation (beam) or the implantation of radiation seeds.

Wyatt is now back on antibiotics again ... The same IV one he was on at home at least for another 24 hours till we find out which one will treat this new infection. Urology should see him in the morning to talk about what the options are for dealing with his catheter.

Wyatt and his mom, Ashley, would like to send a HUGE thank you to everyone, for your thoughts, prayers, and donations. They are so grateful to know that so many people care and are offering so many types of assistance to their family!

 

Update #2 - Wyatt Update - 10/5/12

He is now into his third week of Chemo. He is still doing well with the Chemo part that is. The cathiter part we are still having issues with. His hair is falling out in clumps now and just any time he moves it comes out. The plan was to shave his head yesterday but he was in severe pain and well, will shave it over the weekend...when Ryder comes home so I can shave both their heads!! His Pah came to spend time with him and that really lifts his spirits. He was even excited about riding in Pahs truck :) After irrigating the cath last night he has been much better today, its actually draining and he's eating, drinking and playing. Next Wednesday will be the day I learn what the plan will be with surgery and radiation. He has received many cards, gifts and other things and we will be working on thank you cards during this upcoming week long hospital stay.

Update #1:  Wyatt Update - 10/3/12

He is still pretty angry about all thats going on. He's just not a happy camper. We are home though. We got to leave around 9 last night. The infection he has can't be cured by oral antibiotics so he came home with his port accessed and the visiting nurse should be here soon with the equipment and meds. The news that I have to share next was hard to take in...they did another ultrasound on his bladder and since the tumor has taken over all the way up to the kidney tubes now ( and a good chance into the muscle wall ) Wyatt will have to hold off on radiation and will be having his bladder and prostate removed completely. It's a very serious surgery, will take 6+ hours and then he will have a urostomy bag for 3 years while they clear the rest of the cancer. They will then make him a new bladder and hope everything works the way it should. If not, he will have a cath the rest of his life...we will know more next Wednesday.

 

Hello, and thank you for taking the time to come to my cause.  My name is Justin Anzalone and I am raising money on behalf of my four year old second cousin, Wyatt, who was diagnosed with Rhabdomyosarcoma on September 6th, 2012 while in the hospital for a routine bladder operation.  His mother, my cousin Ashley, is a divorced mother of two.  

We are attempting to raise $1000 to help cover the cost of travel and childcare for my cousin Ashley.  Each trip to the hospital for chemotherapy is a 4 hour round trip.  

Wyatt’s little brother, Ryder, is currently staying with his great-grandmother
and grandfather at their home in Charlevoix, since there is no one able to
care for him nearby for days and nights at a time.

Wyatt’s and Ryder’s grandmother is dealing with her own medical issue,
which is preventing her from being with Ashley and the boy’s (as well as
her job).

Any and all funds that we raise will be going directly to my cousin Ashley to assist her financially (e.g. hospital bills and travel expenses)

I recognize that without your contributions, providing the assistance that my family so desparately needs would be impossible, so we would like to recognize your contribution with perks!  They include:

Level I - A personal thank you card from Wyatt.

Level II -  The perks listed under Level I as well as a Team Wyatt T-shirt, to be debuted shortly.

If you are unable to contribute financially, we encourage you to cross-post this across various social media platforms.  We want to raise awareness of childhood cancer and its devastating effect on families.  There are share tools on this site that are conveniently placed for quick and easy distribution.
story_txt:
Wyatt Update #4 – October 27
Wyatt’s family had a great birthday party on October 27 to celebrate himturning 4 years old on October 29! There were lots of family and friendsthere, great food and cake (thanks to everyone for their help!) and someawesome birthday gifts for Wyatt (as well as some great little-brother giftsfor Ryder!).
Wyatt had spent most of the week leading up to his party in the hospitalagain. He developed another bladder infection, and had some problemswith his chemo port site. So they cultured his urine, which took a few daysto grow out, and had to sedate him in order to insert a new line for deliveryof his morphine and the new antibiotics for infection. He also receivedanother chemo treatment. Luckily, they were able to discharge him onFriday, and we were all very happy that he felt up to attending his birthdayparty on Saturday. He seemed to enjoy it quite a bit, though you could tellhe certainly wasn’t feeling like his old self. He had to wear a mask duringthe entire event to protect him from germs, since his immune system is socompromised. But boy, what a trooper he is - he never complained aboutthat once!
Wyatt is scheduled to have an MRI on Monday, October 29 (his actualbirthday), to assess his current condition in regards to spread of thedisease. We are all hoping for good news! Then, he is scheduled to havesurgery on Friday, Nov. 2 to have his bladder and prostate removed. It willbe a lengthy surgery, estimated by his urologist to last appx. 8 hours.
Let's keep positive thoughts flowing Wyatt's way - we will post updates aswe get them!
Wyatt's family thanks everyone for all of the support!
 
Update #3 - Wyatt Update - 10/12/12
Wyatt has been admitted to Detroit Children’s Hospital for his next round ofchemotherapy treatment. He will receive chemotherapy everyday for 5 days, go home for 2 days, and then be re-admitted for another round of 5 day treatment. The plan right now is that he’ll then have an MRI to see if any tumor shrinkage has occurred, and to access whether there has been any spread of the tumor through the bladder wall, sphincter muscle or any other organs. He is scheduled for surgery to remove the bladder and prostate (and possibly the sphincter muscle) on November 2. Amount of spread of the disease will determine whether the doctors will plan on using radiation as part of his treatment. That will consist of either traditional radiation (beam) or the implantation of radiation seeds.
Wyatt is now back on antibiotics again ... The same IV one he was on at home at least for another 24 hours till we find out which one will treat this new infection. Urology should see him in the morning to talk about what the options are for dealing with his catheter.
Wyatt and his mom, Ashley, would like to send a HUGE thank you to everyone, for your thoughts, prayers, and donations. They are so grateful to know that so many people care and are offering so many types of assistance to their family!
 
Update #2 - Wyatt Update - 10/5/12
He is now into his third week of Chemo. He is still doing well with the Chemo part that is. The cathiter part we are still having issues with. His hair is falling out in clumps now and just any time he moves it comes out. The plan was to shave his head yesterday but he was in severe pain and well, will shave it over the weekend...when Ryder comes home so I can shave both their heads!! His Pah came to spend time with him and that really lifts his spirits. He was even excited about riding in Pahs truck :) After irrigating the cath last night he has been much better today, its actually draining and he's eating, drinking and playing. Next Wednesday will be the day I learn what the plan will be with surgery and radiation. He has received many cards, gifts and other things and we will be working on thank you cards during this upcoming week long hospital stay.
Update #1:  Wyatt Update - 10/3/12
He is still pretty angry about all thats going on. He's just not a happy camper. We are home though. We got to leave around 9 last night. The infection he has can't be cured by oral antibiotics so he came home with his port accessed and the visiting nurse should be here soon with the equipment and meds. The news that I have to share next was hard to take in...they did another ultrasound on his bladder and since the tumor has taken over all the way up to the kidney tubes now ( and a good chance into the muscle wall ) Wyatt will have to hold off on radiation and will be having his bladder and prostate removed completely. It's a very serious surgery, will take 6+ hours and then he will have a urostomy bag for 3 years while they clear the rest of the cancer. They will then make him a new bladder and hope everything works the way it should. If not, he will have a cath the rest of his life...we will know more next Wednesday.

We are attempting to raise $1000 to help cover the cost of travel and childcare for my cousin Ashley.  Each trip to the hospital for chemotherapy is a 4 hour round trip.  
Wyatt’s little brother, Ryder, is currently staying with his great-grandmotherand grandfather at their home in Charlevoix, since there is no one able tocare for him nearby for days and nights at a time.
Wyatt’s and Ryder’s grandmother is dealing with her own medical issue,which is preventing her from being with Ashley and the boy’s (as well asher job).
Any and all funds that we raise will be going directly to my cousin Ashley to assist her financially (e.g. hospital bills and travel expenses)
I recognize that without your contributions, providing the assistance that my family so desparately needs would be impossible, so we would like to recognize your contribution with perks!  They include:
